byline.contributor: Makiko Inoue, Hisako Ueno and Becky Zhuang contributed reporting from Tokyo, and Motoko Rich from New York.

lead_paragraph: The emperor spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties.

headline.print_headline: Japan’s Emperor Humbly Asks: Let Me Retire
headline.main: At 82, Emperor Akihito of Japan Wants to Retire. Will Japan Let Him?

snippet: The emperor spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties....
abstract: Emperor Akihito of Japan, in televised speech to nation, humbly announces that he would like to abdicate his throne because of ailing health, but Japanese law will not allow him to do so; opinion surveys suggest that public overwhelmingly supports Emperor Akihito’s wishes to step down, but amending law could revive contentious issue over allowing a woman to be monarch.
